discussion.content: I would say A is correct
I think C. If a host is unable to create components, the VM would be deployed, but remain non-compliant with the assigned policy until CLOMD comes online and creates the objects.

comments.content: Upon further review, Answer is A. From Epping's vSAN Deep Dive book.

discussion.content: I think A is correct. Clomd is required for object creation, If it is not running on one of the hosts then objects cannot be created on that host, therefore there will not be enough hosts to satisfy the default storage policy requirements.

choices.B: VM deployment will complete but VM IO will fail.
choices.D: VM deployment will be deferred by vCenter.
choices.C: VM deployment will complete but performance will be degraded.

questions.question_text: The Cloud Native Storage control plane in vSphere allows an administrator to provision storage directly from which cloud technology?

comments.content: agreed. and Raid 1 is better latency 5 / 6.

discussion.content: I think B is correct. The DB is stripped across multiple disks.

Yes, I agree it's B.
https://blogs.vmware.com/virtualblocks/2019/03/26/considerations-for-running-microsoft-sql-server-workloads-on-vmware-vsan/

Failures to tolerate: Ensure that an option with at least “1 (one) failure to tolerate” is selected. Do not use the option: “No data redundancy”.
Number of disk stripes per object: Use default one (1), and consider spreading the data between multiple VMDKs attached to multiple vSCSI controllers.

Selected Answer: B
is correct 

There is no simple way to state latency and system impact for different levels. Here’s one way we can put it:

RAID 0 and RAID 10 have effectively no latency or impact.
RAID 5 has some latency and impact
RAID 6 has roughly twice as much computational latency and impact as RAID 5
RAID 7 has roughly triple the computational latency and impact as RAID 5

https://blog.storagecraft.com/raid-performance/
